title: Treating hATTR-Related Complications

sections.heading: What Is Hereditary Transthyretin Amyloidosis With Polyneuropathy?
content: Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis with polyneuropathy (hATTR) is a rare disease caused by a change in a gene (known as a mutation) you inherit from one or both of your parents. It causes your liver to make the protein transthyretin (TTR) that clumps together and builds up in your body’s tissues, organs, and nerves. The clumps, called amyloid fibrils, damage your body.

sections.heading: Hereditary Transthyretin Amyloidosis (hATTR) With Polyneuropathy Complications
content: hATTR is a systemic disease, which means it affects your entire body. It also gets worse over time, and you can have different symptoms depending on which of your organs are affected and how seriously. Symptoms usually show up when you’re between the ages of 30-65. The most common complications include heart and nerve problems, but you can also have problems with your kidneys, gut, and eyes. Carpal tunnel syndrome is often the first sign of hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis. Nervous system complications Neuropathy, or damage to your nerves, often is a complication of hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis and includes some of these symptoms: Tingling or numbness in your legs or feet A hard time walking Weakness or pain in your limbs Getting lightheaded when standing Bladder or bowel problems Sexual problems like erectile dysfunction Sensitivity to pain and heat

sections.heading: Cardiac system complications
content: Amyloid fibrils can also build up in your heart, making it hard for it to work properly. The deposits can cause serious damage, including: Congestive heart failure Stiffening and thickening of your heart Coronary artery disease Arrhythmia (irregular heartbeat) Fainting Some patients with cardiac problems might also have: Fatigue Shortness of breath Leg swelling (edema ) Chest pain Kidney complications When you have amyloid deposits in your kidneys, they can damage how your kidneys work, especially how they filter the toxins and proteins from your blood. This can cause nephrotic syndrome, which is when you have too much protein in your pee and you have swelling in your lower legs. Eye complications Harm to your eyes and other ocular disorders can also happen as hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis gets worse. Some of these complications include: Dry eye Amyloid deposits on the iris or lens of your eye Pupil disorders Glaucoma Abnormal vessels in the thin membrane that protects your eye

sections.heading: Treating hATTR-Related Complications
content: There’s no cure for hATTR, but treatments are improving. Liver transplant was once the only therapy, but the FDA has approved many new medications and clinical trials continue to test others. People diagnosed with hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis can have very different symptoms and complications because of how much and where amyloid fibrils are deposited in their tissues and organs. What stage of the disease they’re in also matters. These all make treating it complicated for your doctor. Treating it becomes even more difficult because there are about 136 different genetic variations of hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis. Each type can have its own complications and cause damage to specific tissues and organs. Researchers now suggest your doctors use a multisystem approach, including treating the disease with therapies that are right for you and monitoring signs of the disease as it gets worse. Talk to your doctor and friends and family about your options, and be sure you’re getting the support you need.

sections.heading: Treatment for neurological complications
content: Gene therapies like TTR silencers have improved treatment for hATTR. They break down the TTR protein and stop your body from making it. There are now four TTR silencer drugs approved for treatment of hATTR with neuropathy : Eplontersen (Wainua) Inotersen (Tegsedi) Patisiran (Onpattro) Vutrisiran (Amvuttra) Treatment for cardiac complications Gene therapies are also common for cardiac complications. Drugs like tafamidis (Vyndamax) and tafamidis meglumine (Vyndaqel) slow down the disease but don’t cure it. They do it by stabilizing the TTR protein. The FDA chose not to approve patisiran (Onpattro) for cardiomyopathy from hATTR. Treatment for eye complications Despite the new medications and therapies approved by the FDA for hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis complications, none is designed to stop amyloids from forming in your eyes. Current treatments work on managing your symptoms only. Treatment for kidney complications Depending on the damage to your kidneys, your doctor might talk to you about several options, including: Medications to manage kidney disease ACE inhibitors to slow the progression of kidney disease Diuretics to remove fluids from your blood and reduce swelling Dialysis to remove waste and extra fluid from your blood Kidney transplant
